title: Elderly pet shop owner asked if young boy knew how to skin animals before sexually abusing them
text:
A pet shop owner who indecently assaulted two boys in his store has been sentenced for his decades-old crimes which started by asking victims if they wanted to know how to skin animals.

The man, now 84 and who can't be named for legal reasons, received a 26-month suspended jail sentence in the County Court in Victoria on Monday.

He pleaded guilty to three counts of indecent assault between 1975 and 1977 on two boys who worked at his suburban Melbourne store.

A pet shop owner who indecently assaulted two boys in his store has been sentenced for his decades-old crimes which started by asking victims if they wanted to know how to skin animals (stock image)

'For the next 26 months, you must not offend or otherwise come before the court ... because if you did, I have to re-sentence you on these three charges and I can assure you the options are running out and it would be likely I would be sending you to jail,' Judge Susan Pullen said.

'I have sentenced you as a serious sex offender.'

The first victim, aged 11 to 14 at the time of the abuse, was assaulted in the shop and at an empty house after the man gave him a ride home.

The boy first visited the store to look at birds and buy seed for his budgerigar.

The man asked him if he would like to move some pet food and offered to pay the youngster $5, which he accepted.

Once finished the boy lay on his back and the man said: 'I'll teach you how to skin a fox.'

He undid the boy's zipper and masturbated him before giving him $20 and sending him home.

The first victim, aged 11 to 14 at the time of the abuse, was assaulted in the shop and at an empty house after the man gave him a ride home (stock image)

The abuse continued and on one other occasion included oral sex.

The second victim, aged 10 to 12 at the time, was touched through his clothing by the offender who first asked if the boy wanted to know how to skin a rabbit.

'The victims of your offending have suffered considerably,' Judge Pullen told the man.

The elderly man had an unstable upbringing and is cared for by one of his four daughters.
